section.title: Filters compared to Searches
section.para: The eSciDoc Infrastructure provides two ways to select lists of objects: filters and searches. They differ in their functionality and the data they consider for query execution.

Searches are configurable via configuration-files and can contain configurable search-fields. Search can be configured for all resources stored in fedora. If configured, access policies are evaluated for each resource in the answer set. The answer set will only contain those resources the user has access to. The Search Service implements the SRW/U standard, thus queries are formulated in CQL (Common Query Language). Result sets consist of configurable representations, and support hit-term highlighting, scoring, sorting, and paging. Searches are provided by a dedicated search service.

Filters work on all resources, independent from their status in object lifecycle. Access policies are evaluated for each resource in the answer set. The answer set will only contain those resources the user has access to. Result sets consist of full object representations, support paging and sorting of results. Similar to searches, filter methods are based on the SRU standard, so queries are formulated in CQL. Filter methods are not provided by a dedicated service. Instead, they belong to the APIs of the respective resource services. They always retrieve resources of the same type, i.e. the filter method of the Item service will always retrieve Item representations exclusively. An exception to this rule are the retrieveMembers() methods in the Context and Container service: the result list may contain both Items and Containers.

section.title: Filter Queries
section.para: Filter queries consist of the actual CQL query and additional metadata, provided as parameters. Queries are executed as SRU Search Retrieve Request. The following example shows a query to retrieve an Item with the object identifier escidoc:5 (using the REST-style API):

The explain operation will be described in the following section. For the rest of this section, we will focus on the searchRetrieve operation, which is used for expressing filter queries. The searchRetrieve operation takes up to four parameters:

The definition of <value> differs for each of the parameters:
query: the actual query with a filter name and a search term.
Example: query=/id=escidoc:5
EBNF:
<value> ::= <filter-criteria>
<filter-criteria> ::= <filter-name> <relation> <search-term> (<operator> <filter-name> <relation> <search-term>)*
<filter-name> ::= ( ""/" <local-name> ( "/" <local-name> )* """) | a-z ( A-Z | a-z )*
<local-name> ::= a-z ( A-Z | a-z | DIGIT | "-" )*
For a more extensive explaination of filter names, please refer to the following section.
<relation> ::= "<" | "<=" | "=" | ">=" | ">" | "<>"
<search-term> ::= CHAR*
<operator> ::= "and" | "or"
version: the version of SRU; currently always 1.1.
Example: version=1.1
EBNF:
<value> ::= <major-version> "." <minor-version>
<major-version> ::= DIGIT+
<minor-version ::= DIGIT+
maximumRecords: the maximum number of records you want to retrieve with your request (combined with startRecord, this verb allows for paging through a large result set). The default value is 20. Please be aware that increasing this value may lead to problems with too large result sets, causing out-of-memory conditions.
Example: maximumRecords=10
EBNF:
<value> ::= DIGIT+
startRecord: the offset for the first record in the result set to be retrieved. The offset starts with 1. Setting startRecord to 10 means to skip the first 9 hits in the result set. The default value is 1.
Example: startRecord=20
EBNF:
<value> ::= DIGIT+

The SRU standard defines the searchRetrieve operation as default operation. Thus, it may be omitted in filter queries. SRU requires version as mandatory parameter. All filter methods substitute this parameter if not given explicitly. Thus, all parameters are optional. A filter query with no operation and no parameters will retrieve all accessible resources. section.title: Filter Names
section.para: Every literal value inside the XML representation of an object can be matched by a search term. The appropriate filter name is a path concatenation of the local names of the elements leading to that value. The path concatenation starts with a slash ('/') and does not include the root element of the XML representation. An example may help to understand the general concept: the XML representation of an Item has an <item> root element. It contains a <properties> section with an element <public-status>. In order to match the value of the element <public-status>, the filter name should be set to /properties/public-status. Filter names constructed from local names always include at least one slash, which has a special meaning in CQL. Therefore, such filter names must be enclosed by quotation marks when used in a query.

SRU defines a simple operation for retrieving all valid filter names: the explain operation. The result is a list of all available filter names for the given service API method. The following example shows the explain operation for the Item service (using the REST-style API):

The resulting explain response is an XML document, which lists all filter names as literal values of the element <name> within the <indexInfo> element. The following example shows an excerpt of the explain plan for the Item resource, with filter names highlighted in bold face:

section.title: Special Filter Names
section.para:
There are a number of filter names are not directly derived from the XML representation of resources:
/last-modification-date
: the timestamp of the latest modification of a resource
Typically, only the access rights of the user invoking the filter method are considered for retrieving the accessible resources. In certain cases (e.g., if the invoking user is an administrator), it might be interesting to retrieve resources based on the access rights of another user:
user
: the user id of the user whose access rights should be considered additionally by the filter method.
role
: the role id; can only be used in combination with
user
. If this filter name is omitted, the user filter will consider all roles granted to the user specified in the user filter.

Supplying a user or role id with the user and role filter names will only narrow down the number of retrieved objects. If the provided user id has access to more objects than the user invoking the filter method, the result set will not include additional resources.

Two filter methods (retrieveMembers in Context and Container service) may retrieve resources of different types (Items and Containers). If you want to limit your filter query to a specific representation type, you can use the type filter name:
type
: the resource type of the resource the filter query should be limited to.
Several filter methods define additional filter names, which are specific to them. You will find these filter names described in API documentation of the respective service.

section.title: Filter Criteria
section.para: The combination of the filter name, the relation, and the search term is called filter criteria. Each filter request may contain several filter criteria, combined by the Boolean operators and and or. Allowed relations are <, <=, =, >=, > and <>. You may use parentheses to ensure the correct evaluation order of the logical expression in your query. section.title: Paging Filter Results
section.para: For larger result lists with many hits, it is often convenient to retrieve only subsets of the result list. This is often called ‘paging’. The filter methods enable paging with two request parameters: startRecord and maximumRecords. Both parameters take (positive) integers as values.

The value of startRecord specifies the number of the hit in the result list that should be the first one to be returned by the system. The sequence number of the first hit in the result list is 1, which is as well the default value for this parameter. The value of maximumRecords specifies the number of hits to be retrieved by the system, starting from the hit number specified startRecord value. The default value for maximumRecords is 20.

For paging, the first request should set maximumRecords to a manageable size, e.g. 20. Subsequent requests should then set the value of startRecord to a multiple of maximumRecords + 1 and keep the value of maximumRecords fix. By doing so, you navigate through the complete result list page by page.

All filter methods return an XML document, complying to the SRW/U schema. The XML document includes the SRW/U version (version element), the number of hits in the result set (numberOfRecords element), and the list of matching resources (records element). Each hit is listed as a record element within records, including its full resource representation.
